item.title: Israeli strike hits aid convoy, killing 7 World Central Kitchen workers in Gaza
item.dc:creator: Yuliya Talmazan and Associated Press
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Tuesday his country’s forces had “unintentionally hit innocent people” in the Gaza Strip in the past day, after an airstrike killed seven aid workers with the disaster relief charity World Central Kitchen.

media:content.media:text: The international food aid charity said on April 2 it was pausing its Gaza aid operations after seven of its staff were killed in a "targeted Israeli strike" as they unloaded desperately needed food aid delivered by sea from Cyprus.
media:content.media:description: People gather around a World Central Kitchen vehicle that was hit by an Israeli strike the previous day in Deir al-Balah in the central Gaza Strip on April 2, 2024.

media:content.media:text: World Central Kitchen Gaza
media:content.media:description: Relatives and friends mourned the deaths as they gathered in Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip on Tuesday.

media:content.media:text: World Central Kitchen Aid Worker Funeral
media:content.media:description: The body of a staff member of the U.S.-based aid group was carried through the streets of Rafah during his funeral.

media:content.media:text: World Central Kitchen vehicles struck in Gaza
media:content.media:description: People gathered Tuesday around one of the cars that was hit by the strike in Deir al-Balah in the central Gaza Strip.

item.title: Eight passengers stranded on African island after Norwegian cruise ship left without them
item.dc:creator: Marlene Lenthang and Arnav Jain
item.description: A dream cruise vacation has turned into a nightmare for eight passengers left stranded on the African island of São Tomé and Príncipe after their ship left without them because they were late to return from a private tour.

media:content.media:text: Jill and Jay Campbell.
media:content.media:description: Jill and Jay Campbell.

item.title: DHS attempts to stop a steady stream of guns from America to Haiti
item.dc:creator: Guad Venegas and Fredlyn Pierre Louis
item.description: The Department of Homeland Security is trying to stop the illegal flow of high-powered guns from the U.S. to Haiti, as the Caribbean nation reels from violence and instability wrought by armed groups and gangs.

media:content.media:text: A G-9 federation gang member holds a gun
media:content.media:description: A G-9 federation gang member in the Delmas 3 area in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, on Feb. 22, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Confiscated guns lay on a table
media:content.media:description: Weapons confiscated by HSI Miami are displayed during a press conference to announce a crackdown on the smuggling of firearms to Haiti and other Caribbean nations in 2022.

item.title: U.S. sends more weapons to Israel amid growing calls for cease-fire
item.dc:creator: Matteo Moschella and Abigail Williams and Allie Raffa and Courtney Kube and Yuliya Talmazan
item.description: The U.S. is sending a fresh round of bombs to Israel, two senior administration officials told NBC News, undermining the Biden administration’s public expressions of frustration at Israel’s conduct in the war and its own efforts at brokering a cease-fire.

media:content.media:text: Smoke rises inside the Gaza Strip
media:content.media:description: Smoke rises inside the Gaza Strip, as seen from southern Israel, on March 17.

item.title: GOP Rep. Tim Walberg suggests Gaza should be handled 'like Nagasaki and Hiroshima'
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Cohen and Emma Li and Marin Scott
item.description: Rep. Tim Walberg, R-Mich., said this week that the conflict in Gaza should be over quickly "like Nagasaki and Hiroshima."

media:content.media:text: Rep. Tim Walberg
media:content.media:description: Rep. Tim Walberg, R-Mich., during the House Republicans' news conference at the Capitol on Dec. 6, 2023.

item.title: Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu recovering after hernia surgery, hospital says
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press and Yarden Segev
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is recovering after undergoing hernia surgery Sunday, which was successful, a hospital spokesperson said.

media:content.media:text: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu
media:content.media:description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu addresses the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, in Jerusalem, on Feb. 18, 2024.

item.title: An Israeli airstrike hits a Gaza hospital tent camp, killing 2 Palestinians and hurting journalists
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: An Israeli airstrike hit a tent camp in the courtyard of a crowded hospital in central Gaza on Sunday, killing two Palestinians and wounding another 15, including journalists working nearby.

media:content.media:text: Palestinians carry a wounded person following an Israeli airstrike
media:content.media:description: Palestinians carry a wounded person following an Israeli airstrike near the Al Aqsa hospital in Deir al Balah, Gaza, on Sunday.

item.title: She secretly educated herself to escape Afghanistan. Now, she's working to help women still there
item.dc:creator: Maya Eaglin
item.description: Sola Mahfouz stopped going to school in 2007 when she was an 11-year-old living in Afghanistan.

media:content.media:text: A portrait of Sola Mahfouz

item.title: Meet the families who've taken children as young as 2 to Everest Base Camp
item.dc:creator: Aria Bendix
item.description: A handful of families have taken children as young as 2 years old to Mount Everest Base Camp in recent years. Three of them describe the experience.

media:content.media:text: Hazel Matulis at Everest Base Camp in 2022.
media:content.media:description: Hazel Matulis at Everest Base Camp in 2022.

media:content.media:text: Dimple Laddha took her daughter, Arishka, last year when Arishka was just 6 years old.
media:content.media:description: Dimple Laddha took her daughter, Arishka, to Everest Base Camp last year at 6 years old.

media:content.media:text: Chris and Cindy Matulis with their kids at Everest Base Camp in 2022.

item.title: Looking for leads, not love: Job seekers in China turn Tinder into a networking tool
item.dc:creator: Larissa Gao and Helen Chen
item.description: Young people in China facing an increasingly tough labor market are turning to an unlikely place for help in their job searches: Tinder.

media:content.media:text: Photo Illustration: A man's Tinder profile reads "Looking for Full-tim employment"
media:content.media:description: Some young people in China see Tinder as a way to find potential job leads.

media:content.media:text: China Youth Unemployment
media:content.media:description: University students at a job fair in Wuhan, China, in March.

item.title: How the Israel-Hamas conflict has spread beyond the Mideast
item.dc:creator: Alexander Smith and JoElla Carman and Jiachuan Wu
item.description: Four months into the war, fighting has spread from Gaza to Pakistan.

item.title: Grief and prayers for aid workers killed in Israeli airstrike
item.description: NBC News filmed at Al-Najjar Hospital in Rafah as grieving colleagues helped deal with the bodies of seven World Central Kitchen volunteers, killed by an Israeli airstrike in Deir al-Balah.

media:content.media:title: Grief and prayers for aid workers killed in Israeli airstrike
media:content.media:description: NBC News filmed at Al-Najjar Hospital in Rafah as grieving colleagues helped deal with the bodies of seven World Central Kitchen volunteers, killed by an Israeli airstrike in Deir al-Balah.

item.title: Blinken: World Central Kitchen strike adds to 'record number' of aid worker deaths
item.description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken began his remarks at a press conference in France by addressing the death of seven World Central Kitchen aid workers in Gaza. He expressed his condolences to the loved ones of those lost, called for a "thorough and impartial" investigation and marked how these deaths join a "record number" of humanitarian workers killed in the conflict.

media:content.media:title: Blinken: World Central Kitchen strike adds to 'record number' of aid worker deaths
media:content.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken began his remarks at a press conference in France by addressing the death of seven World Central Kitchen aid workers in Gaza. He expressed his condolences to the loved ones of those lost, called for a "thorough and impartial" investigation and marked how these deaths join a "record number" of humanitarian workers killed in the conflict.

item.title: At least one student dies in Finland school shooting
item.description: A 12-year-old student opened fire at a school in southern Finland, killing at least one student and wounding two others. The suspect was later arrested and an investigation is underway.

media:content.media:title: At least one student dies in Finland school shooting
media:content.media:description: A 12-year-old student opened fire at a school in southern Finland, killing at least one student and wounding two others. The suspect was later arrested and an investigation is underway.

item.title: José Andrés speaks out on reported death of aid workers in Gaza
item.description: Several workers delivering humanitarian aid for the World Central Kitchen have been killed in a reported Israeli airstrike. The group’s founder, Chef José Andrés, released a statement about the tragedy. NBC’s Raf Sanchez reports for TODAY.

media:content.media:title: José Andrés speaks out on reported death of aid workers in Gaza
media:content.media:description: Several workers delivering humanitarian aid for the World Central Kitchen have been killed in a reported Israeli airstrike. The group’s founder, Chef José Andrés, released a statement about the tragedy. NBC’s Raf Sanchez reports for TODAY.

item.title: Supporting the team or the SS? German soccer jersey with No. 44 pulled over Nazi symbolism
item.dc:creator: Mithil Aggarwal
item.description: German soccer fans have been banned from customizing a jersey with the number 44 because of a resemblance to the lightning bolts symbol used by Nazi SS units.

media:content.media:text: An official Germany soccer jersey displaying the number 4 ahead of the upcoming UEFA Euro 2024 championship.
media:content.media:description: An official German soccer jersey displaying No. 4 ahead of the UEFA Euro 2024 championship.

media:content.media:text: Waffen-SS
media:content.media:description: A recruitment poster for the Waffen-SS, circa 1940.

item.title: Peru's president replaces 6 ministers as she battles scandal over luxury watches
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Peruvian President Dina Boluarte replaced six ministers after they resigned as her government is rocked by a political crisis fueled by an alleged illicit enrichment scandal involving luxury watches.

media:content.media:text: Dina Boluarte gives a press conference in Lima in 2023.
media:content.media:description: President Dina Boluarte at a press conference in Lima, Peru, last year.

media:content.media:text: Police guard outside President Dina Boluarte's house.
media:content.media:description: Police outside President Dina Boluarte's house during a raid ordered by the Attorney General's Office in Lima on March 30.

item.title: Fire at an Istanbul nightclub kills at least 29 people
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: A fire at a nightclub in the Turkish city of Istanbul on Tuesday killed at least 29 people, officials and reports said.

media:content.media:text: Relatives of victims react near the site of a fire in a residential building in Istanbul on April 2, 2024.
media:content.media:description: Relatives of victims near the scene of a fire at a Istanbul nightclub on Tuesday.

media:content.media:text: Firefighters work at the scene of a fire in a nightclub in Istanbul Tuesday, April 2, 2024.
media:content.media:description: Firefighters work at the scene of the blaze.

item.title: Benedict backed me up on rights for LGBTQ couples, Pope Francis says
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Pope Francis found an ally in his predecessor Benedict XVI when he spoke in favor of civil partnerships for same-sex couples, the pontiff said in an upcoming new book.

media:content.media:text: Pope Francis and Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI
media:content.media:description: Pope Francis visited Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI in St. Peter's Basilica, Vatican, on Aug. 27, 2022.

item.title: American teenager among 3 killed in an avalanche near the Swiss resort of Zermatt
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: An American teenager and two other people were killed in avalanche near the Swiss resort of Zermatt, police said Tuesday.

media:content.media:credit: Police Cantonale Valaisanne via AFP - Getty Images
media:content.media:text: Search operations after an avalanche at Zermatt ski resort, in Valais, Switzerland
media:content.media:description: Search operations after an avalanche at Zermatt ski resort in Valais, Switzerland, on April 1, 2024.

item.title: Singapore convicts first suspect in record money-laundering case
item.dc:creator: Clement Tan, CNBC
item.description: Singapore on Tuesday sentenced the first person to plead guilty in the Southeast Asian city-state’s biggest money-laundering scandal to a 13-month imprisonment.

media:content.media:text: Evidence Sized Related To One of Singapore's Largest Money Laundering Cases
media:content.media:description: Singapore police seized a Porsche 911 Targa last year from a residence of one of the suspects in the money-laundering case.

item.title: Classmate apprehended after child dies and two injured in Finland school shooting
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Three children were injured in a shooting at a primary school in Finland early Tuesday, and a suspect, who was also a minor, was later apprehended, police said.

media:content.media:text: Finnish police say a number of people were wounded in a shooting at a school outside Helsinki and a suspect was detained. (Markku Ulander/Lehtikuva via AP)
media:content.media:description: Police officers at the scene of Viertola comprehensive school, in Vantaa, Finland on April 2, 2024.

item.title: 9 children killed by old land mine near Afghanistan village
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: An old land mine found by children in eastern Afghanistan exploded while they were playing with it, killing nine children, a Taliban spokesman said Monday.

media:content.media:text: Afghanistan Land Mines
media:content.media:description: A man searches for landmines as part of the HALO (Hazardous Area Life-Support Organization) Trust in Nad-e-Ali village, in Afghanistan's Helmand province in 2021.

item.title: North Korea fires an intermediate-range missile, South Korea says
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: North Korea test-fired a suspected intermediate-range ballistic missile toward waters off its eastern coast Tuesday, South Korea’s military said.

media:content.media:text: A news program airs a file image of a missile launch by North Korea at the Seoul Railway Station in South Korea, on Tuesday, April 2, 2024.
media:content.media:description: A news program airing a file image of a North Korean missile launch at the Seoul Railway Station in South Korea on Tuesday.

item.title: A Brazilian rising political star's killing was a mystery until an explosive federal report
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Explosive revelations in a 500-page Federal Police report allege ties between federal state civil police chief Rivaldo Barbosa and organized crime in the killing of Councilwoman Marielle Franco, a rising political star and Black LGBTQ woman.

media:content.media:text: People carry posters with images of slain Brazilian councilwoman Marielle Franco
media:content.media:description: People carry posters with images of slain Brazilian councilwoman Marielle Franco during a demonstration against racism in Lisbon, Portugal, on Feb. 24.

media:content.media:text: Then-Rio de Janeiro Councilwoman Marielle Franco smiles for a photo
media:content.media:description: Then-Rio de Janeiro councilwoman Marielle Franco in Cinelandia square in Brazil in 2018.

media:content.media:text: Rivaldo Barbosa is escorted by a federal police officer
media:content.media:description: Then-head of the Rio civil police, Rivaldo Barbosa, is escorted by a federal police officer upon arrival at Federal Police headquarters in Rio de Janeiro on March 24.
